code: @Manual{,   title = {citools: Confidence Intervals},   author = {Christina Fillmore and Mike Sprys and Dan Lyrhgoe},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://gsk-biostatistics.github.io/citools/}, }

title: Confidence Intervals
text: goal citools …

title: Confidence Intervals
text: can install development version citools GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("GSK-Biostatistics/citools")

title: Confidence Intervals
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(citools) # Example of CI for proportions x <- c(  TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE,  FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE ) ci_prop_wald(x, conf.level = 0.9) #>  #> ── Wald Confidence Interval without Continuity Correction ────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2399, 0.7601) ci_prop_wilson(x, correct = TRUE) #>  #> ── Wilson Confidence Interval with continuity correction ─────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2366, 0.7634) ci_prop_clopper_pearson(x) #>  #> ── Clopper-Pearson Confidence Interval ───────────────────────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.1871, 0.8129) ci_prop_agresti_coull(x) #>  #> ── Agresti-Coull Confidence Interval ─────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2366, 0.7634) ci_prop_jeffreys(x) #>  #> ── Jeffreys Interval ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2235, 0.7765) # Example of CI for difference of proportions  # Generate binary samples responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 3/10 - 9/10 #> • Estimate: -0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.8406, -0.17)

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: Calculates Agresti-Coull interval (created Alan Agresti Brent Coull) (95% CI) adding two successes two failures data using Wald formula construct CI.

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
code: ci_prop_agresti_coull(x, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Agresti-Coull CI — ci_prop_agresti_coull
text: $$ \left( \frac{\tilde{p} + z^2_{\alpha/2}/2}{n + z^2_{\alpha/2}} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\tilde{p}(1 - \tilde{p})}{n} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n^2}} \right)$$

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: Calculates Clopper-Pearson interval calling stats::binom.test(). Also referred exact method.

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
code: ci_prop_clopper_pearson(x, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Clopper-Pearson CI — ci_prop_clopper_pearson
text: $$ \left( \frac{k}{n} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\frac{k}{n}(1-\frac{k}{n})}{n} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n^2}} \right) / \left( 1 + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{n} \right)$$

what: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: Calculates Miettinen-Nurminen (MN) confidence interval difference two proportions. method can accurate traditional methods, especially small sample sizes proportions close 0 1.

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
code: ci_prop_diff_mn(x, by, conf.level = 0.95, delta = NULL, data = NULL)

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 delta (numeric)  Optionally single number vector numbers -1 1 (inclusive) set difference two groups null hypothesis. provided, function returns test statistic p-value delta hypothesis. data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: list containing following components: estimate point estimate difference proportions (p_x - p_y) conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used delta delta value(s) used statistic Z-Statistic null hypothesis based given 'delta' p.value p-value null hypothesis based given 'delta' method Description method used ("Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval") delta provided statistic p.value NULL

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: function implements Miettinen-Nurminen method compute confidence intervals difference two proportions. approach: Calculates Miettinen-Nurminen score test statistic different possible values proportion difference (delta) Identifies delta values test statistic equals critical value corresponding desired confidence level Returns boundary values confidence interval limits method uses score test small-sample correction factor, making accurate normal approximation methods, especially small samples extreme proportions. equation test statistics follows: $$H_0: \hat{d}-\delta <= 0 \qquad \text{vs.} \qquad H_1: \hat{d}-\delta > 0$$ $$ T_\delta = \frac{\hat{p_x} - \hat{p_y} - \delta}{\sigma_{mn}(\delta)}$$ \(\hat{p_*} = s_*/n_*\) represent observed number successes divided number participant group. \(\sigma_{mn}(\delta)\) function delta values create following equation" \(\tilde{p_*}\) represent MLE proportions. $$ \sigma_{mn}(\delta) = \sqrt{\left[\frac{\tilde{p_y}(1-\tilde{p_y})}{n_x}+\frac{\tilde{p_x}(1-\tilde{p_x})}{n_y} \right]\left(\frac{N}{N-1}\right)} $$ \( \tilde{p_x} = 2p\cdot{cos()} - \frac{L_2}{3L_3}\) \( \tilde{p_y} = \tilde{p_x} + \delta\) : \(p = \pm \sqrt{\frac{L_2^2}{(3L_3)^2} - \frac{L_1}{3L_3}}\) \(= 1/3[\pi + cos^{-1}(q/p^3)]\) \(q = \frac{L_2^3}{(3L_3)^3} - \frac{L_1L_2}{6L_3^2} + \frac{L_0}{2L_3}\) \(L_3 = n_x + n_y \) \(L_2 = (n_x + 2 n_y)\delta - N - (s_x + s_y)\) \(L_1 = (n_y\delta - L_3 - 2s_y)\delta + s_x + s_y\) \(L_0 = s_y\delta(1-\delta)\) information equations see Miettinen (1985)

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
text: Miettinen, O. S., & Nurminen, M. (1985). Comparative analysis two rates. Statistics Medicine, 4(2), 213-226.

title: Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn
code: # Generate binary samples responses <- expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), times = c(10, 10))  # Calculate 95% confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 3/10 - 9/10 #> • Estimate: -0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.8406, -0.17)  # Calculate 99% confidence interval ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm, conf.level = 0.99) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 3/10 - 9/10 #> • Estimate: -0.6 #> • 99% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.8792, -0.0218)  # Calculate the p-value under the null hypothesis delta = -0.1 ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm, delta = -0.1) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 3/10 - 9/10 #> • Estimate: -0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.8406, -0.17) #>  #> ── Delta  #> • At -0.1 the statistic is -2.248 and the p-value is 0.0123 #> cli-150-365  # Calculate from a data.frame data <- data.frame(responses, arm) ci_prop_diff_mn(x = responses, by = arm, data = data) #>  #> ── Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ────────────────────────────────────── #> • 3/10 - 9/10 #> • Estimate: -0.6 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.8406, -0.17)

what: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: Calculates Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen (MN) confidence intervals corresponding point estimates difference two proportions

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
code: ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(   x,   by,   strata,   method = c("score", "summary score"),   conf.level = 0.95,   delta = NULL,   data = NULL )

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) (string)  character factor vector exactly two unique levels identifying two groups compare. Can also column name data frame provided data argument. strata (numeric)  vector specifying stratum observation. needs length x multiple x multiple levels strata present. Can also column name (vector column names quoted) data frame provided data argument. method (string)  Specifying CIs calculated. must equal either 'score' 'summary score'. See details information implementation differences. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 delta (numeric)  Optionally single number vector numbers -1 1 (inclusive) set difference two groups null hypothesis. provided, function returns test statistic p-value delta hypothesis. data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: list containing following components: estimate point estimate difference proportions (p_x - p_y) conf.low Lower bound confidence interval conf.high Upper bound confidence interval conf.level confidence level used delta delta value(s) used statistic Z-Statistic null hypothesis based given 'delta' p.value p-value null hypothesis based given 'delta' method Description method used ("Stratified {method} Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval") delta provided statistic p.value NULL

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: function implements stratified Miettinen-Nurminen method compute confidence intervals difference two proportions across multiple strata. $$H_0: \hat{d}-\delta <= 0 \qquad \text{vs.} \qquad H_1: \hat{d}-\delta > 0$$ "score" method, approach: Calculates weights stratum \(w_i = \frac{n_{xi} \cdot n_{yi}}{n_{xi} + n_{yi}}\) Computes overall weighted difference \(\hat{d} = \frac{\sum w_i \hat{p}_{xi}}{\sum w_i} -           \frac{\sum w_i \hat{p}_{yi}}{\sum w_i}\) Uses stratified test statistic: $$Z_{\delta} = \frac{\hat{d} - \delta}           {\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^k \left(\frac{w_i}{\sum w_i}\right)^2 \cdot \hat{\sigma}_{mn}^2({d})}}$$ Finds range values \(\delta\) stratified test statistic (\(Z_\delta\)) falls acceptance region \(\{ Z_\delta < z_{\alpha/2}\}\) \(\hat{\sigma}_{mn}^2(\hat{d})\) Miettinen-Nurminen variance estimate. See details ci_prop_diff_mn() \(\hat{\sigma}_{mn}^2(\delta)\) calculated. "summary score" method, function: point estimate stratified risk difference weighted average midpoints within-stratum MN confidence intervals: $$       \hat{d}_{\text{S}} = \sum_i \hat{d}_i w_i       $$ Define \(s_i\) width CI \(\)th stratum divided \(2 \times z_{\alpha/2}\) stratum weights given $$     w_i = \left( \frac{1}{s_i^2} \right) \bigg/ \sum_i \left( \frac{1}{s_i^2} \right)     $$ variance \(\hat{d}_{\text{S}} \) computed $$      \widehat{\text{Var}}(\hat{d}_{\text{S}}) = \frac{1}{\sum_i \left( \frac{1}{s_i^2} \right) }     $$ Confidence limits stratified risk difference estimate $$     \hat{d}_{\text{S}} \pm \left( z_{\alpha /2} \times \widehat{\text{Var}}(\hat{d}_{\text{S}}) \right)     $$

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
text: Miettinen, O. S., & Nurminen, M. (1985). Comparative analysis two rates. Statistics Medicine, 4(2), 213-226. Common Risk Difference :: Base SAS(R) 9.4 Procedures Guide: Statistical Procedures, Third Edition

title: Stratified Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval for Difference in Proportions — ci_prop_diff_mn_strata
code: # Generate binary samples with strata responses <- expand(c(9, 3, 7, 2), c(10, 10, 10, 10)) arm <- rep(c("treat", "control"), 20) strata <- rep(c("stratum1", "stratum2"), times = c(20, 20))  # Calculate stratified confidence interval for difference in proportions ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 9/20 - 12/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: -0.15 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.4338, 0.1606)  # Using the summary score method ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata,                       method = "summary score") #>  #> ── Stratified Summary Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────── #> • 9/20 - 12/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 0.511, stratum2 = 0.489 #> • Estimate: -0.126 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.4113, 0.1586)  # Calculate 99% confidence interval ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata,                       conf.level = 0.99) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 9/20 - 12/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: -0.15 #> • 99% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.5072, 0.2509)  # Calculate p-value under null hypothesis delta = 0.2 ci_prop_diff_mn_strata(x = responses, by = arm, strata = strata,                       delta = 0.2) #>  #> ── Stratified Score Miettinen-Nurminen Confidence Interval ───────────────────── #> • 9/20 - 12/20 #> • Weights: stratum1 = 5, stratum2 = 5 #> • Estimate: -0.15 #> • 95% Confidence Interval: #>   (-0.4338, 0.1606) #>  #> ── Delta  #> • At 0.2 the statistic is -2.224 and the p-value is 0.0131 #> cli-150-444

title: Jeffreys CI — ci_prop_jeffreys
text: Calculates Jeffreys interval, equal-tailed interval based non-informative Jeffreys prior binomial proportion.

title: Jeffreys CI — ci_prop_jeffreys
code: ci_prop_jeffreys(x, conf.level = 0.95, data = NULL)

title: Jeffreys CI — ci_prop_jeffreys
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Jeffreys CI — ci_prop_jeffreys
text: $$\left( \text{Beta}\left(\frac{k}{2} + \frac{1}{2}, \frac{n - k}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\right)_\alpha, \text{Beta}\left(\frac{k}{2} + \frac{1}{2}, \frac{n - k}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\right)_{1-\alpha} \right)$$

title: Wald CI — ci_prop_wald
text: Calculates Wald interval following usual textbook definition single proportion confidence interval using normal approximation.

title: Wald CI — ci_prop_wald
code: ci_prop_wald(x, conf.level = 0.95, correct = FALSE, data = NULL)

title: Wald CI — ci_prop_wald
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 correct (logical) apply continuity correction. data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Wald CI — ci_prop_wald
text: $$\hat{p} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1 - \hat{p})}{n}}$$

title: Wald CI — ci_prop_wald
code: # example code x <- c( TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE )  ci_prop_wald(x, conf.level = 0.9) #>  #> ── Wald Confidence Interval without Continuity Correction ────────────────────── #> • 5 responses out of 10 #> • Estimate: 0.5 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.2399, 0.7601)

title: Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson
text: Calculates Wilson interval calling stats::prop.test(). Also referred Wilson score interval.

title: Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson
code: ci_prop_wilson(x, conf.level = 0.95, correct = FALSE, data = NULL)

title: Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 correct (logical) apply continuity correction. data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson
text: $$\frac{\hat{p} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{2n} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1 - \hat{p})}{n} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n^2}}}{1 + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{n}}$$

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
text: Calculates stratified Wilson confidence interval unequal proportions described Xin YA, Su XG. Stratified Wilson Newcombe confidence intervals multiple binomial proportions. Statistics Biopharmaceutical Research. 2010;2(3).

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
code: ci_prop_wilson_strata(   x,   strata,   weights = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   max.iterations = 10L,   correct = FALSE,   data = NULL )

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
text: x (binary/numeric/logical) vector binary values, .e. logical vector, numeric values c(0, 1) strata (numeric)  vector specifying stratum observation. needs length x multiple x multiple levels strata present. Can also column name (vector column names quoted) data frame provided data argument. weights (numeric) weights level strata. NULL, estimated using iterative algorithm minimizes weighted squared length confidence interval. conf.level (scalar numeric)  scalar (0,1) indicating confidence level. Default 0.95 max.iterations (positive integer) maximum number iterations iterative procedure used find estimates optimal weights. correct (scalar logical) include continuity correction. information, see example stats::prop.test(). data (data.frame)  Optional data frame containing variables specified x .

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
text: $$\frac{\hat{p}_j + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{2n_j} \pm z_{\alpha/2} \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}_j(1 - \hat{p}_j)}{n_j} + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{4n_j^2}}}{1 + \frac{z^2_{\alpha/2}}{n_j}}$$

title: Stratified Wilson CI — ci_prop_wilson_strata
code: # Stratified Wilson confidence interval with unequal probabilities  set.seed(1) rsp <- sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 100, TRUE) strata_data <- data.frame(   x = sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 100, TRUE),   "f1" = sample(c("a", "b"), 100, TRUE),   "f2" = sample(c("x", "y", "z"), 100, TRUE),   stringsAsFactors = TRUE ) strata <- interaction(strata_data) n_strata <- ncol(table(rsp, strata)) # Number of strata  ci_prop_wilson_strata(   x = rsp, strata = strata,   conf.level = 0.90 ) #>  #> ── Stratified Wilson Confidence Interval without continuity correction ───────── #> • 49 responses out of 100 #> • Weights: FALSE.a.x = 0.054, TRUE.a.x = 0.095, FALSE.b.x = 0.106, TRUE.b.x = #> 0.151, FALSE.a.y = 0.061, TRUE.a.y = 0.064, FALSE.b.y = 0.072, TRUE.b.y = #> 0.095, FALSE.a.z = 0.089, TRUE.a.z = 0.081, FALSE.b.z = 0.061, TRUE.b.z = 0.072 #> • Estimate: 0.49 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.4155, 0.5689)  # Not automatic setting of weights ci_prop_wilson_strata(   x = rsp, strata = strata,   weights = rep(1 / n_strata, n_strata),   conf.level = 0.90 ) #>  #> ── Stratified Wilson Confidence Interval without continuity correction ───────── #> • 49 responses out of 100 #> • Weights: 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, 0.083, #> 0.083, 0.083, 0.083 #> • Estimate: 0.49 #> • 90% Confidence Interval: #>   (0.4231, 0.5827)

what: Function to combine strata via interaction if strata is passed as a vector — combine_strata
title: Function to combine strata via interaction if strata is passed as a vector — combine_strata
text: Function combine strata via interaction strata passed vector

title: Function to combine strata via interaction if strata is passed as a vector — combine_strata
code: combine_strata(x, strata)

what: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: Converts count data (number successes total sample size) binary vector TRUE/FALSE values. useful converting summary statistics back raw data format analysis functions require individual-level data.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
code: expand(x, n)

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: x Integer (vector integers) representing number successes. n Integer (vector integers) representing total number participants.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: logical vector TRUE represents success FALSE represents failure. length vector equals sum sample sizes.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
text: pair values x n, function creates vector x TRUE values followed n-x FALSE values. multiple pairs provided, resulting vectors concatenated order.

title: Expand Count Data into Binary Vectors — expand
code: # Convert 4 successes out of 13 participants to binary data expand(4, 13) #>  [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #> [13] FALSE  # Convert multiple groups of data # Group 1: 9 successes out of 10 # Group 2: 3 successes out of 10 expand(c(9, 3), c(10, 10)) #>  [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE #> [13]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

what: To get the n's and response totals with out without strata — get_counts
title: To get the n's and response totals with out without strata — get_counts
text: get n's response totals without strata

title: To get the n's and response totals with out without strata — get_counts
code: get_counts(x, by, strata = 1)
